metadata.review_notes: Updated INR targets to reflect 2019 EULAR/ACR guidelines and ongoing clinical debate

content.definition: An acquired autoimmune thrombophilia characterized by persistent antiphospholipid antibodies and clinical manifestations of arterial and/or venous thrombosis and/or pregnancy morbidity. APS is unique among thrombophilias in causing both arterial and venous thrombosis.

classification.secondary_aps: APS with underlying disease (SLE most common)

laboratory_criteria: Lupus anticoagulant positive (2 occasions 12 weeks apart)

diagnosis.triple_positive: All 3 antibodies present = highest thrombosis risk

long_term.warfarin_preferred: INR target 2-3 for most patients including venous events
long_term.arterial_events: INR 2-3 recommended (2019 EULAR/ACR); some experts use 3-4 for recurrent arterial events - individualize
long_term.doacs: NOT recommended (inferior efficacy in APS - TRAPS trial)

learning_objectives: Know the diagnostic criteria for APS
Understand that APS causes both arterial AND venous thrombosis
Know why warfarin is preferred over DOACs
clinical_pearls: APS is ONLY thrombophilia that causes BOTH arterial and venous thrombosis
Warfarin is SUPERIOR to DOACs in APS - DOACs have higher failure rate (TRAPS trial)
Must confirm antibodies on 2 occasions 12 weeks apart
Paradox: lupus anticoagulant causes thrombosis (not bleeding)
Catastrophic APS: multi-organ failure - high mortality
INR 2-3 is standard; higher targets for arterial events are debated
